Go Weekly

Interactive Release Notes for Go 1.23 â€” If you find traditional release notes hard going, this interactive alternative with inline executable code snippets might help you get a grip on some of 1.23's changes before the final release nextÂ month.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ’¡ While we're on the topic.. Go 1.23 Release Candidate 2 has beenÂ released.

First Impressions of Go 1.23's Range-over-Func Feature â€” When the author read Goâ€™s newest iteration proposal, he felt a bit intimidated, but decided to kick the tires and share his experiences. Now? He lovesÂ it!

Jonathan Hall

Run GitHub Actions Up to 2x Faster at Half theÂ Cost â€” Blacksmith runs your GitHub Actions substantially faster by running them on modern gaming CPUs. Integrating Blacksmith is a one-line code change. 100+ companies like GitBook, Superblocks, and Slope use Blacksmith to help developers merge codeÂ faster.

Blacksmith sponsor

Hash-Based Bisect Debugging in Compilers and Runtimes â€” If youâ€™ve ever had to debug a large set of changes as part of an unfamiliar code base, this approach may feel like magic, so much so that Russ and others have created a CLI (bisect) to make the task easier. The explanation of using binary search, git bisect, and the bisect CLI here are veryÂ informative.

Russ Cox

ï£¿Â How I Build Simple Mac Apps using Go â€” The creator of DarwinKit, a set of native Apple APIs for Go, shows off how he uses it to create basic MacÂ apps.

Jeff Lindsay

Live Website Updates with Go, SSE, and HTMX â€” Showing real-time updates on a site may steer you toward WebSockets, but going the SSE (Server-Sent Events) route with HTMX provides a solid and simpler experience.

MiÅ‚osz SmÃ³Å‚ka

Safeguarding Changes using the Plan-Execute Pattern â€” A pattern used by tools like Terraform where a preview of changes is shown before applying them. Tom creates a simple example of importing data into a database while highlighting new, changed, and removedÂ entities.

Tom Nick

FusionAuth sponsor

ğŸ”’Â govulncheck 1.1: Find Vulnerable Dependencies in Your GoÂ Code â€” Govulncheck uses static analysis on your code, along with the Go Vulnerability Database, to report relevant known vulnerabilities to you. Thereâ€™s an official tutorial on how to use itÂ too.

Julie Qiu (Go Security Team)

LinDB: A Go-Powered Time Series Database System â€” Joining a long line of Go-powered database systems comes LinDB, a new performance and availability-focused time-series database that can be accessed via a REST API. GitHubÂ repo.

Lin Labs Inc.

Kratos 2.8: A Go Framework for Cloud-Based Microservices â€” A â€œmicroservice-oriented governance frameworkâ€ built aroundÂ HTTP/gRPC.

Kratos

  • go-redis 9.6 â€“ Redis clientÂ library. v9.6 adds support for hash field expiration commands as introduced in RedisÂ 7.4.

  • go-resiliency 1.7 â€“ Resiliency patterns forÂ Go. Circuit-breaker, deadlineÂ &Â more.

  • Permify 0.10 â€“ Google Zanzibar-inspiredÂ authorization.

  • Buf 1.35 â€“ CLI tool for working with ProtocolÂ Buffers.

  • Delve 1.23 â€“ Popular debugging tool for GoÂ code.

item.title: ã€It's about timeã€‘æ˜¯æ—¶å€™äº†
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹515 â€” July 16, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Quartz: A Deterministic Time Testing Library â€” A new mocking library designed for testing code that relies on time, by introducing a little determinism and control to proceedings.. GitHubÂ repo.

Spike Curtis

Go Range Iterators Demystified â€” In Go 1.22 (behind a flag) or 1.23 (currently in the release candidate stage), you can use the range keyword to iterate over custom collection types. Zach walks (iterates?) us through from the basics up to some more complexÂ examples.

Zach Musgrave

WorkOS: The Modern Identity Platform for B2BÂ SaaS â€” Start selling to enterprise customers with just a few lines of code. WorkOS provides flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and RBAC in minutes. It's used by hundreds of high-growth startups including Perplexity, Vercel, Drata, &Â Webflow.

WorkOS sponsor

Building a Binary Search Tree with SIMD and Go's Assembler â€” When you want a little more performance than Go provides naturally, or access to underlying CPU features unavailable in Go, leaning on assembly language is one way to do it. ClÃ©ment shows a practical exampleÂ here.

ClÃ©ment Jean

âš ï¸ Note that the tutorial above assumes knowledge of Go's assembler and doesnâ€™t walk through the build process. Iâ€™ve put together the pieces of ClÃ©mentâ€™s code into a single GitHub Gist to make it easier to reproduce for yourself,Â though.

IN BRIEF:

  • The oft (and fairly)-criticized TIOBE Index of programming langauge popularity has had an update with Go moving up to 7th place, after only entering the top 10 earlier this year. A big relative jump, even if you question theÂ methodology.

  • ğŸ§ Mat Ryer went on the Go Time podcast to talk about how he builds HTTP services in Go nowadays, after 13 years of doing justÂ that.

â–¶Â Â Give Your Go App 'Superpowers' with an Embedded NATSÂ Server â€” NATS is a lightweight real-time client/server messaging system, but a cool feature of NATS is you can embed it directly into a Go app and take advantage of its features without relying on a separateÂ server.

Synadio

Profiling in Go: A Practical Guide â€” Pinpoint performance bottlenecks in your apps by profiling their activity and optimizing things based on theÂ results.

Noam Yadgar

Kafka Is Dead, Long Live Kafka â€” Kafka is polarizing, yet ubiquitous. What if you could run Kafka as a single, stateless Go binary and reduce yourÂ costs?

WarpStream sponsor

ğŸ“„ Mastering SOLID Principles with Go Examples Alex Pliutau

ğŸ“„ Docker Best Practices: Choosing Between RUN, CMD, and ENTRYPOINT Jay Schmidt (Docker)

ğŸ“„ Demystifying Go Strings Andrei Boar

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Fyne 2.5: GUI App Framework for Desktop, Mobile and Web â€” Fyne isnâ€™t a new project, but itâ€™s been years since we featured it, and itâ€™s a pretty neat way to build GUI and mobile apps with Go. v2.5 is a big release with support for Wayland as well as internationalization. It requires Go 1.19+. GitHubÂ repo.

Fyne Team

ğŸ’¡ In Writing GUI apps doesn't have to be painful, Nikola UbaviÄ‡ explains how he considered numerous languages and GUI app development approaches before settling on Go andÂ FyneÂ (above).

Minigrad: Andrej Karpathy's Micrograd in Go â€” A neural network library using an autograd approach. Itâ€™s essentially Andrej Karpathyâ€™s (previously of OpenAI) Micrograd implementation in Go, rather thanÂ Python.

Jeet

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meetings should be more like code reviews. We're building a product for that and looking for software leaders to join the beta. Apply here.

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Protect your application infrastructure running on AWS with this time tested and essential security checklist. Download now!

ğŸ¥Â Iris seeks Sr. Backend Engineer for edge-deployed Go/Rust dev. Work on an AI-powered robotic camera platform. Remote, equity, competitive pay.

Build Tools for Go â€” If the out-of-the-box build tools arenâ€™t getting it done, hereâ€™s list of open source build tools to consider, including Mage and Taskfile.

Inkmi

Chiko: An Elegant gRPC TUI Client â€” Uses the popular tview terminal UI widget library to offer a way to interact with gRPCÂ services.

felangga

timediff: Produce Human Readable, Relative Time Differences â€” For example: timediff.TimeDiff(time.Now().Add(-3 * time.Minute)) would produce â€œ3 minutesÂ agoâ€.

MergeStat

  • GoReleaser 2.1 â€“ Build and release Go binaries for severalÂ platforms.

  • phonenumbers 1.4 â€“ Go port of Google's libphonenumber library.

  • gocron 2.10 â€“ Run Go functions at pre-determinedÂ intervals.

  • go-github 63.0 â€“ GitHub v3 API clientÂ library.

  • fq 0.12 â€“ Like jq for binaryÂ formats.

#â€‹518 â€” August 6, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ–ï¸ Hi! We're taking next week off for a brief summer break. We'll be back with our next issue on August 20. Also, if possible, can you click an item or two? We're going to be doing some 'list cleaning' soon and it's helpful to know if you're still keen to receive the newsletterÂ â€“ thanks!Â :-)
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Russ Cox Steps Down as Tech Lead of Go â€” Russ has been instrumental in many of Goâ€™s developments having led the project for 12 years, but itâ€™s time for a change with Austin Clements taking his position. But Russ isnâ€™t leaving the Go world. Indeed, he's already deep into a new project (seeÂ next)..

Russ Cox

Oscar: An Open-Source Contributor Agent Architecture â€” As Russ steps away as Go tech lead, heâ€™s stepping into more work on Oscar, an AI agent system to help maintain open-source projects. The first bot, Gaby, is already up and running on Goâ€™s issue tracker, with more toÂ come.

Russ Cox

Go! Unlock Your Tech Potential with Ardan Labs Consulting â€” Struggling with skill gaps, development speed or complex tech challenges? Ardan Labs specializes in Go, Rust, Docker and K8s to accelerate your software development, optimize architecture, and manage tech debt. Let us supercharge yourÂ team!

Ardan Labs Consulting sponsor

What's the Best Static Analysis Tool for Go? â€” Static analysis can be a valuable part of an appâ€™s quality toolchain, run by both developers and pipelines. But there are many options, official and otherwise, so which to choose? The answer is (kinda) all ofÂ themâ€¦?

Nick Tobey (DoltHub)

A 10 Week Go Backend Engineer Onboarding Plan â€” Stream has published the onboarding program they use for Go developers, which covers the basics of Go, databases, HTTP, and more. This is a great idea and sets expectations if youâ€™re looking forÂ work.

Stream

Did You Know About Instruments? â€” Instruments is a macOS app that allows you to create various traces and profiles of running applications. It offers quite the toolset, as indicated by Thorstenâ€™s palpableÂ enthusiasm.

Thorsten Ball

Implementing HTTP/0.9 from Scratch â€” The first instalment of a â€œHTTP from Scratchâ€ series digging into the history of the protocol underpinning theÂ Web.

Kevin McDonald

ğŸ“º 5 Levels of Go Error Handling RageCageCodes

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

approf: A Native macOS App for pprof â€” An app experience for viewing the results from pprof profiling that includes drag/drop, reordering, light/dark mode, and savedÂ sessions.

Moderato

Glamour: Stylesheet-based Markdown Rendering for Your CLIÂ Apps â€” Glamour lets you render simple Markdown from your app but then have styles applied to it so that it looks more colorful and elegant once it lands in theÂ terminal. Another great piece of work from the folks at Charm.

Charm

Your Fastest Path to Production â€” Build, deploy, and scale your apps with unparalleled ease â€“ from your first user to yourÂ billionth.

Render sponsor

mimetype: Library for Detecting MIME Types and Extensions â€” Supporting 173 different types, you pass in binary data, a data stream or filename and, hopefully, find out what type of data youâ€™re workingÂ with.

Gabriel Vasile

go-sqlbuilder: A Flexible SQL String Builder Library â€” Originally focused on MySQL and Postgres, it now supports SQL Server, SQLite, CQL, and more, too. Lets you use structs as a â€˜light weight ORMâ€™, and now also supports Common Table Expression andÂ ILIKE.

Huan Du

Minimock: A Tool to Generate Mocks from Interface Declarations â€” Generates statically typed mocks and helpers, is fully integrated with the testing package, and supportsÂ generics.

Juno Inc.

  • River 0.11 â€“ Fast and reliable Postgres-powered background jobs forÂ Go.

  • env 11.2 â€“ Zero dependency way to parse env variables intoÂ structs.

  • Dgraph 24.0 - Native GraphQL database with a graphÂ backend.

  • ğŸ‡¯ğŸ‡µ Kagome 2.10 â€“ Japanese morphologicalÂ analyzer.

  • Resty 2.14 â€“ Simple HTTP and REST clientÂ library.

  • webdav 5.1 â€“ Standalone WebDAVÂ server.

  • GoBGP 3.29 â€“ BGP implementation inÂ Go.

As mentioned earlier, we're taking a week off and will be back on August 20.

If you didn't find anything to click in this issue, how about enjoying â–¶ï¸Â thisÂ particularly high quality 1950s-themed attempt at the classic Steamed Hams gag from The Simpsons? ğŸ˜„

#â€‹517 â€” July 30, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Cogent Core: A New GUI Framework for Go â€” A new GUI framework with a â€œcode once and run everywhereâ€ promise for multiple platforms. It aims to be simpler to use than Gio and more powerful than Fyne. Curiously, Cogentâ€™s web site itself is built in the framework and compiled to WASM to work on the Web. Thereâ€™s also â–¶ï¸Â a quick screencast pitching you on theÂ framework.

Kai O'Reilly and Randy O'Reilly

Go Features by Version (or What's in Which Go) â€” A list of features and the versions in which they first appeared. Proof, if any were needed, that the progress made to Go isn't slowing down. (And if you want to get up to speed with Go 1.23, here are the notes forÂ you.)

Anton Zhiyanov
